symptoms.name: Skin sores
symptoms.severity: Variable, can be painless or painful
symptoms.pattern: One or more sores, may change in size and appearance over time, often resembling a volcano with a raised edge and central crater; some sores may be covered by a scab; swollen glands near sores may be present

symptoms.name: Enlarged spleen and liver
symptoms.pattern: Present in visceral leishmaniasis; usually spleen is larger than liver

symptoms.name: Swollen glands
symptoms.pattern: May be present in visceral leishmaniasis and cutaneous leishmaniasis

symptoms.name: Ulcers in nose, mouth, or throat
Low blood counts (anemia, low white blood cell count, low platelet count)
Macular, papular, or nodular rash (Post-kala-azar dermal leishmaniasis)
symptoms.pattern: Usually on face, upper arms, and trunk; occurs months to years after kala-azar treatment

physical_findings: Skin sores (variable size, appearance, and presence of scabs)
Macular, papular, or nodular rash (Post-kala-azar dermal leishmaniasis)

lab_values.Complete blood count: Low red blood cell count (anemia), low white blood cell count, low platelet count (visceral leishmaniasis)
lab_values.Parasitological tests: Presence of Leishmania parasites in tissue samples (ulcers, spleen, lymph node, bone marrow)
lab_values.Serological tests: Detection of Leishmania antibodies (limited value in cutaneous leishmaniasis, potential cross-reactivity with Trypanosoma cruzi)

risk_factors: Living in rural areas of tropical or subtropical regions
Poor housing and domestic sanitary conditions
Human behavior (sleeping outside or on the ground)
Diets lacking protein-energy, iron, vitamin A, and zinc
Movement of people into areas with high transmission
Changes in urbanization, deforestation, or human incursion into forested areas
Climate change (changes in temperature and rainfall)

required: Parasitological confirmation (microscopic examination of tissue samples for amastigotes)
supportive: Serological tests (limited value in cutaneous leishmaniasis)
